intro: Pyxidaria procumbens, commonly known as the creeping pyxidaria, is a low-growing perennial plant native to the temperate regions of the United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes familiar plants like carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-white flowers arranged in umbels, typical of its family. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodlands or along stream banks. Due to its ornamental value and ecological benefits, it is sometimes cultivated in native plant gardens.
